item.title: Faker providers for project specific data structure fakes, in Python
item.description: I am a big fan of Faker for testing. I find having a random mock data generator keeps tests clean. In fact, I tend to extend Faker with project specific providers. Here's how

item.title: Poetry-driven python project template with cookiecutter
item.description: The python toolchain I use for my small projects doesn't change very often. It makes sense to save it somewhere and the then replicate it whenever I start a project. Or even better, use cookiecutter and a config file to generate it.

item.title: Migrating away from Google: Hello Proton Mail!
item.description: Google informed me they would start charging me for letting me use their mail servers with my gotofritz.net domain. Fair enough, infrastructure costs money. But if I have to pay, why pay them? I'm can shop around. And so I did.

item.title: Removing duplicates from youtube playlists with a Python script
item.description: Thanks to a bug while copying a youtube playlist with a Python script, I ended up with a lot of duplicates videos in the playlist. Surprisingly, the YouTube interface doesn't let you remove them. So I put together another small Python script

item.title: Adding videos to a youtube playlists via a terminal python script
item.description: I wanted to duplicate another user's playlist to one of my free google accounts. But it's no longer possible from the web interface. None of the methods described in various SO answers are functional, they are obsolete. But it can be done with a Python script in your terminal.

item.title: Migrating Thunderbird message filters from another machine
item.description: Thunderbird doesn't sync message filters. Its roots are from ancient times, before distributed computing was prevalent. If you want to copy your filters from one machine to another you have to do it the old-fashioned way, by copying config files

item.title: Stopping cSpell from using .gitignore
item.description: cSpell is a spelling plugin for VS Code. Not my favourite, but the only one I found. It isn't particularly well documented though. It avoids spell checking files in .gitignore. To stop that, you need to add "cSpell.useGitignore": false, to your settings

item.title: Remove lines matching some patterns from all files in a dir
item.description: A CLI task I find myself doing often with sed

item.title: How I built a markdown drive static website with SvelteKit and Tailwind
item.description: In my last post I ported my existing blog to SvelteKit, to get to used to it. Now I am going to build a new version from scratch, using markdown and tailwind. I will use Matt Jennings's excellent SvelteKit blog template as seed.

item.title: I rebuilt my website with SvelteKit
item.description: Building a static website with Sveltekit and markdown is hard going at first. But just when I was about to give up I stumbled on some blog posts and boilerplates that helped me crack it. I may still switch to Astro later though

item.title: Reordering audio files in a FAT USB stick
item.description: I copy audiobooks from CDs to USB sticks to play them in cars and random device like old radios. But often those devices play the files out of order. Reordering files in FAT USB sticks is harder than I thought. Luckily, a chap by the name of Boris Leidner has written a useful tool for that.

item.title: Fixing autoformatting Django templates in Visual Studio Co
item.description: Prettier autoformatting screws up Django html templates in Visual Studio Code. For example, it puts tags on the same line when they shouldn't be. The fix is pretty simple and involves a couple of different formatting extension.

item.title: How I install python on OS X in 2022
item.description: There are many different ways of doing it; my favourite involves using pyenv

item.title: Setting up and managing Thunderbird for OS X
item.description: I have recently switched to Thunderbird from Gyazmail, the obscure mail program I have been using for years. Here are some setup tips that worked for me

item.title: Using the 'Say' command to make OS X talk, and fixing it when it gets stuck
item.description: One can easily make OS X read out text from the CLI with the say command. But what to do when it gets stuck and stops working?

item.title: Setting up a Logitech Vertical MX mouse with a Mac
item.description: I got myself one of these ergonomic mice, connected it to my Mac and configured the extra buttons. I like it

item.title: Setting CSS values dynamically in Svelte
item.description: If you are used to React's Styled Components, assigning CSS values dynamically in Svelte can be baffling at first.

item.title: A countdown clock using requestAnimationFrame, a state machine, and vanilla JS
item.description: I wanted to play with state machines and requestAnimationFrame in vanilla JS, so I came up with the idea of a simple countdown clock.

item.title: Removing album ratings from Apple Music App
item.description: Apple Music / iTunes "helpfully" adds ratings to songs for you, based on the ratings of the other songs in the album. This messes some of my smart playlists up. Only Applescript will get rid of those ratings

item.title: OS X Apps I use
item.description: All the OS X apps I use - for when I need to reinstall a new machine.

item.title: Backing up a hard disk to another in OS X
item.description: Time Machine does its own backup magic, but sometimes you just simply want two identical copies of the same hard disk. For that rsync is the way to go

item.title: Stop Chrome navigating back when swiping horizontally
item.description: If you try to use Google Chrome on a small window on a laptop, perhaps because you are comparing two web pages side by side, swiping left or right doesn't move the page around, but it jumps to the previous or next page. Here's how to prevent that on OS X.

item.title: How To Avoid sudo npm
item.description: You know the story. You try to do npm install hipster-package on OS X and you get a whole load of errors; the easy way out is to just use sudo npm install. Everyone, however, keep saying how that is bad idea. But how do you make npm work without sudo? It's quite simple actually

item.title: Pretty printing XML
item.description: tidy is a command line tool for formatting XML and HTML. Also available as a Visual Studio Code Extension

item.title: OS X Software Update from the Command Line
item.description: Software updates can be quite tedious - you have to click a lot of buttons, then get into the Apple Store etc. But you can avoid all that by running it from the command line.

item.title: OS X DNS lookups too slow for local hosts
item.description: OS can sometimes take forever to resolve hosts setup on my local machine. Here is how I solved it.

item.title: Directory listings in Apache 2.4
item.description: Yosemite updates Apache to 2.4. A couple of things stopped working from my previous installation, including autogenerated directory listings. Here's how I got them back.

item.title: dotfiles
item.description: Storing your CLI config files (.bash_profile and all the rest) on github makes sense - as a backup, but also to compare and learn.

item.title: Install a specific version of a tool on OS X with Homebrew
item.description: Sometimes you need to install an older version of a package with Homebrew. Here's how I installed version 1.7.10 of Subversion

item.title: Copying sourcefiles without .git folders with cpio
item.description: Sometimes you need to copy your local version of a project under subversion to a new location, without all the .git stuff. Here's a couple of ways of doing it.

item.title: Dealing with extended attributes on OS X
item.description: Extended attributes store extra information about files in OS X. They replaced resource forks. Sometimes those extra hidden files confuse peripherals (e.g. mp3 players) that were not setup to deal with them. Here are some terminal commands to handle them.

item.title: Making a simple voice recording on a Mac
item.description: To make a quick voice recording with OS X: open Quick Time Player, under the File menu there is a "New. Audio Recording" entry. It automatically saves .mov files in your Movies folder, which you can then open in Audacity or the editor of your choice.

item.title: Escaping $ in replace strings in Javascript
item.description: To have a $ in your replace strings in Javascript regular expressions, it needs to be escaped with another $

item.title: Changing title of CMD window
item.description: title some words will change the title of your cmd shell in Window The title will be `some words` instead of `C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe`. Handy if you have a few of them open and can't tell them apart.

item.title: Combining images with ImageMagick
item.description: Assorted ImageMagick commands for combining images

item.title: A Google Apps Script boilerplate
item.description: I used to do a lot of Google Apps Script (GAS) programming, but Google's never seemed to interested in that product so I gave up. Here I document a simple boilerplate project so that I don't forget how to do it.

item.title: Advanced Evernote search
item.description: It isn't immediately obvious, but Evernote offers advanced search operators.

item.title: A good place for scripts in OSX
item.description: Where to put unix based scripts on a Mac without them getting in the way? Simple: create a bin folder in your home directory, and add it to the path: export PATH=~/bin:$PATH

item.title: SVN status codes
item.description: Running the status command in the command line version of subversion returns a list of files with a one letter code in front of each file name. Here's a list of those one letter codes and what they mean.

item.title: Joining PDF files in OS X from the command line
item.description: In OS X, PDF files can be concatenated manually using Preview. But if you are happy using Terminal there's an easier way, thanks to a Python script installed by default in /System/Library/Automator

item.title: Finding files inside an archive with Terminal
item.description: Looking for files inside an archive, without having to extract them first using Apple's Terminal.

item.title: Finding recently changed files with Terminal
item.description: Finding files that were changed in the last day, sorted by size, using Apple's Terminal

item.title: Batch unrar from the command line on Mac OS X
item.description: Rar is a popular archive format on the web. When I need to unarchive several rar files at once, I use RarLab's command line tool. Here's how
